comments.commentBody: It is always appropriate for the government to be involved in medical licensing so as to protect the public.
Until men are able to give birth, then yes, it IS always about women's health.

The Supreme Court?
What STATES may do?
The only time any of this B# can be ruled on by the United States Supreme Court is if a person SUE'S their State. The lawsuit has to work up through the layers of the Courts before then can rule on it.
Roe v Wade started in The Northern Texas District Court
The actuall court is in Dallas Texas
How dare they! We, every one of us, is assured the right of privacy, and what can be more private than our bodies.
Technology has not moved on to define the so-called viability of the fetus. Scientists still argue about this.The Supreme Court does not make this decision, because they don't know either.
It's not about eugenics, it's about a woman's right to choose--to have the choice to make about her own life.
Me so hungry now.

Uhh ... it did. That's why Seattle only won by a point.

To be fair, the pass interference called on Chancellor against Rudolph that set up the go-ahead FG for the Vikings was a bad call.

Did anyone ask Walsh if he aimed left to avoid Sherman's block attempt, considering how close he came to blocking his previous attempt.
One would think the cold would have favored the Vikings.
Great idea for using up my green garlic, and when I give some to friends, I'll include the recipe.

This interview with Keith Strickland addresses some of these questions, and brings David Bowie in, too!
http://archive.fabmagazine.com/features/341/b52.html

In those days it didn't matter whether you were in the boondocks or on Christopher Street. It was still about having eyes to see and ears to hear.
Two of the hot TV series lately - Downton Abbey and Mad Men - have included gay characters explaining to, erm, establishment characters, in some way or another, "it isn't clear; you have to pick up on little things," one in 1920 and another in 1965. The thing is, it didn't change after Stonewall - and it hasn't changed now. The fact that people might choose to be open/come out is very different from expecting that people do/will. The interview addresses the point.

It seems to also be on the point of this thread, to note that the emus emufied my last post for several hours, doing a thorough investigation that might make Mr. McCarthy proud.

À bas les Green Checks!

Well, this thread has certainly told me a lot about things I completely didn't know or even think about.

I knew that there is or was a band called the B52s. And that's all I knew. Not anything they'd ever sung, any venue they'd ever played, where they were from, or their sexual identity/orientation. Same for Debbie Harry (Deb's "pogo" link), except that she has been a reliable supporter of HIV/AIDS organizations. So I admire her as a person, even though I don't know her music or anything else about her.

Anyway, I've always had lousy (borderline nonexistent) gaydar.

I note that several commenters don't seem to have Rock Lobster in their vocab, musical or otherwise - the article linked here hints at why Rock Lobster is very well known and appreciated by me and many like me, at least those old enough to remember when this was in the news:

Confirming once again that Republicans see women as  incubators first and foremost.
Of course, in the end, everything is America's fault.  1500 years of ongoing ethnic and cultural cleansing in the Middle East and North Africa, and the West is all to blame.

Mr. Zarif,

It isn't that some countries stand in the way of constructive engagement, but that all sides are racing for supremacy, by any means necessary and at the expense of millions of suffering human beings.

Western powers have long taken advantage of intra-sectarian strife among Muslims to divide, conquer, and reap the benefits of commercial interests. But here we are now, with a Levant in shambles and your country and Saudi Arabia vying for supremacy.

The US government and European powers would do well to learn lessons from the recent past, not choose any sides but insist on the kinds of moral choices the people of the region can build upon, not on the basis of this or that religious zealotry, but on humanitarian and humanist principles.

“As far as you can avoid it, do not give grief to anyone. Never inflict your rage on another. If you hope for eternal rest, feel the pain yourself; but don’t hurt others.”
― Omar Khayyám, Quatrains

---

www.rimaregas.com

We might dump him.

But the General Assembly is locked in through severe gerrymandering until the 2020 decennial reapportionment.

Given North Carolina's boom, there is likely to be a reckoning for the Republicans.

This is an outrageous abuse of women's freedom and physicians' freedom to make the decisions that are best for them.

I hope this galvanizes North Carolina voters to get rid of the Republicans in November...
I'm with DL, and find the current proceedings quite aghastly. Our Molly I, could see the humour in just about everything, but I think even she would be spending  some time crouched in a closet.

I've made this dish 2x before with great success. Now we are going to be doubling the recipe. Anyone have experience cooking 2 8-10 lb bone in pork butts at same time? Do we need to allow more cooking time? Also wi this be enough to serve 16? Thanks!

"The growth of the job market while this statistic remains week is simply due to population growth..."

Actually, none of the growth of the job market is due to population growth since babies and toddlers don't work. Since it is is simply wrong to mix together people who want jobs and those who don't, the best measure is appropriately called "not in the labor force, want a job now" (BLS series ID LNS15026639). Last I checked (last month) the percentage of people in this category was lower than it was at comparable points following the milder recessions of 1981-82 and 1990-91. And that is true whether the denominator is the labor force or the Civilian Noninstitutional Population.

So, the question is: following the worst recession since the Great Depression, how is it that we are doing better when it comes to people who aren't in the labor force even though they want jobs than we did following two recent milder recessions?

I agree with you that a lot of recipes using coconut milk andor curry need a little bit of sugar to balance out the flavors. You definitely do not want to use sweetened coconut milk, or cream of coconut as it is commonly called. That's only for pina coladas and pretty much nothing else!

This was really good. Agreed that it can get a little thin, would cut the water ration by half. Also had to add sugar, maybe because I used unsweetened coconut milk?

Sri Lankan food is the best.

Not sure that this is worth the trouble.  It tastes good, but too much liquid and a bit bland.  I, too, would cut up the apricots, use less liquid. Canned tomatoes worked well.  I may add some acid--lime juice? Vinegar?--to the leftovers and some more heat.

This was delicious and warming for a cold winter night; we will definitely make this again.  We doubled the roasted veggies part and kept everything else the same.  (Oh, we also halved the amount of oil in the dressing).  To die for.

By the wisdom of Gov. McCrory and his colleagues it would be perfectly consistent if similar legislation was passed to require the results of prostate and proctology exams and prescriptions for Viagra submitted to the state.

Try checking the cauliflower for doneness at 40 minutes. I did mine in 60 minutes and feel it might be a bit too tender.

Skipped almonds, butter, rinsing of the anchovy, just dumped the can of anchovy into pan, and browned the garlic and red peppers in it, added little more olive oil, and vinegar. This is more like the traditional bagna cauda, but worked great on the cauliflower wedges. Just spoon a little on and spread around.

I needed closer to 3c. of AP flour to get a sticky consistency. Less than that was just runny. I did use White Lily APF, which has a lower gluten % than most APF. Overall though, once I got the dough right, very good dish. Packed full of flavor.

Had a similar problem rolling, especially with the chocolate chips, which seemed to want to escape every time. The extra tablespoon of flour helped. I bet these would be good with some coconut oil substituted in for canola, maybe half and half?
Peter, it's difficult for me to imagine a woman who has either an abortion or a baby using it to kill several people.  It is not the same with guns.  Perhaps you disagree.

He was mayor of Charlotte for a very long time, during which it boomed and turned blue. His City Council was composed primarily of Democrats and in Charlotte's council-manager form of governance, he held little actual power.

But the essential truth about him is that he is the emptiest of suits.

"Mr. McCrory, a former mayor of Charlotte, has labored at times to balance his pragmatic inclinations"--I don't believe he has or had any such inclinations.  He may be a bit less fanatical than his legislature, but they have always been pretty much in tune, from what I've read about them.
